holidays.name: New Year's Day
holidays.description: Russians celebrate New Year’s Day in accordance with the Gregorian calendar on January 1.

holidays.name: New Year Holiday Week
holidays.description: A 2012 decree has extended the number of days, and the dates for the New Year break.

holidays.name: New Year Holiday Week
holidays.description: A 2012 decree has extended the number of days, and the dates for the New Year break.

holidays.name: New Year Holiday Week
holidays.description: A 2012 decree has extended the number of days, and the dates for the New Year break.

holidays.name: Orthodox Christmas Day
holidays.description: Many Russians celebrate Christmas Day on January 7 in the Gregorian calendar, which corresponds to December 25 in the Julian calendar.

holidays.name: New Year Holiday Week
holidays.description: A 2012 decree has extended the number of days, and the dates for the New Year break.

holidays.name: Valentine's Day
holidays.description: Valentine’s Day is a special time to celebrate love, romance and friendship.

holidays.name: Defender of the Fatherland Day
holidays.description: Many Russians celebrate Defender of the Fatherland Day on February 23, when they honor military forces and veterans.

holidays.name: Special Operations Forces Day
holidays.description: Special Operations Forces Day in Russia falls on February 27.

holidays.name: International Women's Day
holidays.description: Many Russians pay tribute to women’s role in Russian society by celebrating International Women’s Day on March 8.

holidays.name: Isra and Mi'raj
holidays.description: Isra and Mi'raj (Isra Me'raj, Israa and Mi'raaj, Laylat Al-Isra wa Al-Miraj, Lailat al Miraj, Night Journey and Ascension to Heaven) marks the night that the Prophet Mohammad traveled from Mecca to Jerusalem, ascended to heaven and returned.

holidays.name: Orthodox Easter Day
holidays.description: Millions of Orthodox Christians around the world often celebrate Easter Sunday at a different time to the date set by many western churches.

holidays.name: Spring and Labor Day
holidays.description: For many Russians, Spring and Labor Day, which falls on May 1, is a family holiday and a time for relaxation.

holidays.name: Spring and Labor Day Holiday
holidays.description: A 2012 decree has changed the number of days, and the dates for the Spring and Labor Day Holidays.

holidays.name: Spring and Labor Day Holiday
holidays.description: A 2012 decree has changed the number of days, and the dates for the Spring and Labor Day Holidays.

holidays.name: Ramadan starts
holidays.description: Ramadan is a period of prayer, reflection and fasting for many Muslims worldwide. It is the ninth month in the Islamic calendar.

holidays.name: Victory Day
holidays.description: One of the biggest Russian holidays, Victory Day, marks Germany’s surrender to the Soviet Union in 1945, ending one of the bloodiest wars in Russia’s history.

holidays.name: Defender of the Fatherland Day holiday
Lailat al-Qadr
holidays.description: Laylat al-Qadr commmemorates the time when Mohammad received the first verses of the Koran (Qu'ran).

holidays.name: Eid al-Fitr
holidays.description: Eid-al-Fitr is a holiday to mark the end of the Islamic month of Ramadan, during which Muslims fast during the hours of daylight.

holidays.name: Russia Day
holidays.description: Russia Day, annually celebrated on June 12, marks the beginning of democratic reforms in Russia and is one of the newest holidays in the Russian Federation.

holidays.name: Eid al-Adha
holidays.description: Eid al-Adha (Id ul-Adha) is an Islamic festival falling on the 10th day of the month of Dhul Hijja (Thou al-Hijja) to commemorate the willingness of Ibrahim (Abraham) to sacrifice his son.

holidays.name: Muharram
holidays.description: Muharram is the first month of the Islamic calendar and a time of remembrance or mourning.

holidays.name: Unity Day
holidays.description: Unity Day, which is on November 4, is one of the newest and the most controversial holidays in Russia.

holidays.name: The Prophet's Birthday
holidays.description: Mawlid, or Milad, marks the birth of the Islamic prophet Muhammed, or Mohamed, in the year 570 of the Gregorian calendar.
